title.narrative: Strengthened access to and capacity among selected African NHRIs to use online data tools for furthering implementation of HRE/SDG 4.7

16 staff from 8 NHRIs have documented a positive learning effect against pre-established learningand behavioural goals. At least 8 NHRIs in Africa have collected data on HRE/SDG 4.7 using DIHR’s online tool.

target.value: 16 staff from 8 NHRIs have documented a positive learning effect against pre-established learningand behavioural goals At least 8 NHRIs in Africa have collected data on HRE/SDG 4.7 using DIHR’s online tool.

actual.value: - Only 7 staff from participating NHRIs documented a positive learning effect after the regional workshop against pre-established learning goals and compared to their pre-test scores. 9 participants remained at the same level. However, a granular review of the improvements should a positive learning effect in many critical areas e.g. key international human rights treaties linked to the human rights education element of SDG 4.7; the four components of the World Programme for Human Rights Education with links to SDG indicator 4.7.1; the role of NHRIs in implementing the 2030 Agenda. - 10 NHRIs in Africa collected data on the human rights education elements of SDG 4.7, using the online data tool. It is important to highlight that not all the data has been quality checked or finally reviewed by the relevant national human rights institution.

title.narrative: Enhanced institutionalisation of human rights-based data collection on HRE/SDG 4.7 and strengthened national implementation of its HRE elements in two African countries
NHRIs in Africa are collaborating with relevant state actors to further the institutionalisation of human rights-based data collection on SDG 4.7 and progress in human rights education.

target.value: 2 NHRIs in two different African countries in Eastern or Southern Africa are i) working with relevant state actors on the institutionalisation of data collection for SDG and human rights monitoring processes ii) using the human-rights data to further progress at the national level on implementation of HRE/SDG 4.7. iii) directly inputting to SDG Follow up and review processes or UN reporting using the human rights data collected via the online tool.

actual.value: 3 NHRIs are collaborating with a range of relevant national actors to further HRE in national frameworks. However, it has not been possible within the short time-frame of the small grants to secure the institutionalization of human rights-based data collection, although one NHRI, the Ethiopian Human Rights Commission, has included in their recently developed Action Plan that they will produce annual reports on the HRE elements of SDG 4.7.

target.value: Human rights data on the current implementation of the HRE elements of SDG 4.7 will be available for state actors. NHRIs. CSOs and educational institutions in five African countries through the use of DIHR’s online tool. NHRIs from the five countries have shared observations on the HRE scenarios in their respective countries based on the data generated. and discussed how to take strategic follow-up action to further States implementation of HRE.

actual.value: One regional workshop was carried out online on 27 and 28 August 2020 in close co-operation with NANHRI, the Network of African National Human Rights Institutions. The workshop was attended by 24 NHRI participants from 8 NHRIs in Kenya, Ethiopia, Gambia, Ghana, Nigeria, Zimbabwe, Malawi, and Cameroon.

title.narrative: Recognition of an integrated human rights-based HRE/SDG 4.7 tool for improved monitoring, reporting and accountability on human rights education is enhanced
NHRIs, states and other stakeholders expressing interest in using the online tool at national level

target.value: Two new NHRIs. states or other stakeholders express interest in using the tool.

actual.value: NHRIs, states and other stakeholders have indicated their interest in using the online tool. UNESCO, the custodian for SDG 4, has announced that its Technical Group on the Indicators for SDG 4 will pilot the Institute’s SDG 4.7/HRE Indicator Tool for official data collection on SDG 4.7. This is a major achievement towards the institutionalisation of data collection on human rights education linked both to human rights standards and to the political commitments under SDG 4.7 and an impetus to states to secure periodic reporting.
